official-title.#text:
To direct the Secretary of the Interior to conduct a
		  global rare earth element assessment, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Resource Assessment of Rare Earths Act
			 of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Global rare earth
			 element resource assessment

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and in
			 coordination with the heads of national geological surveys where available,
			 shall submit to the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the United States Geological Survey

Committee on Natural Resources of the House of
			 Representatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
a comprehensive report on global rare earth element resources and potential
			 future global supply. Such report shall use the best available data and
			 include—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate

text.#text:
Not later than 3
			 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the

the identity and quantity of individual
			 rare earth elements in known deposits;

recommendations,
			 developed in consultation with other appropriate agencies, on areas of need for
			 future geologic research related to—

other minerals
			 that are critical based on the impact of a potential supply restriction and the
			 likelihood of a supply restriction; and

analysis, developed with participation by
			 the National Minerals Information Center and in consultation with appropriate
			 agencies, of the rare earth elements supply chain and associated processes and
			 products, including mining, processing, separation, metal production, alloy
			 production, and manufacturing of products sold to end users.

any element in the
			 lanthanides group of elements, which consists of lanthanum, cerium,
			 praseodymium, neodymium, promethium, samarium, europium, gadolinium, terbium,
			 dysprosium, holmium, erbium, thulium, ytterbium, and lutetium;

$10,000,000 for the period
			 of fiscal years 2014 through 2016
